Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: ISN: Modeling Operations of Human Trafficking Networks for Effective Interdiction

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) will enhance the national health, prosperity, and welfare by contributing to our understanding of and ability to disrupt the operations of illicit sex trafficking networks. Sex trafficking within the United States is a complex social and criminal enterprise interwoven within the illegal labor market for sex, and entails highly exploitative, often violent, means to extract profit. Because trafficking is hidden, illegal and dangerous it is difficult to gather the data needed to develop effective quantitative operational models of trafficking networks and their response to interventions. To tackle this challenge, the project will build a collaborative team of social scientists, operations researchers, law enforcement personnel, and sex trafficking survivors to analyze law enforcement data for network modeling. This award will support identification of unique aspects of sex trafficking networks that will inform mathematical models that can support effective decisions to disrupt these networks. The project will produce sex trafficking network data that can be used as a basis for testing such models. Sex trafficking victims disproportionally come from our most vulnerable communities, including those who live in poverty and have had prior experiences of sexual assault, family violence, out of home placement, homelessness, and other traumatic experiences. This project is expected to have a particular impact on the health, prosperity, and welfare of these populations.

This research will apply qualitative analysis of law enforcement case files and stakeholder interviews to identify the most important features of sex trafficking networks, including their composition, how they adapt to interdictions, and the dependencies between their physical and cyber networks. The research team will identify the underlying structure and key features of sex trafficking networks in these cases, construct node-arc network representations of the data, and identify key changes to current network interdiction models to ensure applicability in disrupting sex trafficking operations. The project will begin to fill the most significant gaps in the interdiction literature that limits its applicability to disrupting human trafficking networks. The resulting network data will be made publicly available and the study team will detail methods for replicating the network generation process to develop additional trafficking network datasets, including labor trafficking networks.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Institution.Name: University of Minnesota-Twin Cities
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Human trafficking for sexual exploitation is a human rights violation with significant public health implications. It is hidden, illegal, and dangerous; therefore it is difficult to research and identify effective prevention, intervention and disruption strategies. Significant ethical challenges confront research on human trafficking, including risks of re-traumatization of victim/survivors. Modeling human trafficking operations and networks with mathematics offers the possibility of identifying effective actions to disrupt and prevent victimization while weighing the relative merits and costs/benefits of different strategies. This information is vital for stakeholders in the field to make informed decisions about disruption efforts. Models are only as good as the data used to build them. Useful models require accurate empirical data to inform assumptions and results. Yet, we lack a research-based understanding of the unique aspects of trafficking networks including their structure, function and processes. This project addresses this information gap. We formed a unique, transdisciplinary team to gather a wide-range of data from different sources and develop mathematical network models of trafficking operations. The project built a highly-functional team including qualitative researchers with expertise on trafficking, operations researchers, survivors of human trafficking, and law enforcement. We achieved the following high-level goals:

(1) Identified operational structures of sex trafficking networks that make them unique among illicit supply networks.

(2) Identified and translated qualitative data necessary to populate dynamic operations research models, such as interdiction models, that can disrupt such networks.

(3) Built a highly functional cross-disciplinary and multi-sector team.

(4) Worked together to verify that model assumptions are accurate by triangulating sources and exploring the project findings with a survivor-centered advisory group.

(5) Identified ethical challenges and considerations in modeling, such as the need to acknowledge the complexity of human experiences and the inability of models to truly portray the violence and coercion embedded within human trafficking.

The team completed all project objectives, including the following outcomes. We conducted 10 scoping interviews with stakeholders including police, service providers and survivors of trafficking to identify key elements of human trafficking operations and networks. We also conducted a thorough review of the literature and a secondary review of relevant interview data collected by past projects of PI Martin (N=246).

A survivor-centered advisory group was convened to review all aspects of the project. This group met almost monthly for 18 months to highlight information missing from other sources and raise ethical and moral implications of the work. The University of Minnesota created a data-sharing agreement with the Minnesota Bureau of Criminal Apprehension (BCA) to conduct a pilot review of comprehensive investigative case files (N=2) to better understand the complexity of networks of human trafficking and the type of data contained in police case files. Each case was more than 1,000 pages long. 

The team created a data processing framework to transform key qualitative data into network data necessary for mathematical modeling. We also developed computational code to create node/arc visualizations of human trafficking operations. Network data was collected from publically available documents from 15 federally prosecuted trafficking cases and BCA cases using our processing framework. A new concept and initial computational code for a network generator was created. It will enable us to develop generic models of human trafficking networks based on empirical data and address ethical considerations with respect to confidentiality, privacy, and re-traumatization of victims.

During the grant period, the team presented our findings to diverse audiences and drafted manuscripts for publication related to our modeling approach, computational code, qualitative understanding of operational networks and structure, and team science.

Using a deliberate process of team-building in combination with a meta-study of ourselves, we cultivated shared language, better cross-disciplinary understanding, and deep working relationships among the transdisciplinary and cross-sector team. We documented our collaborative process using qualitative research. Based on this project we refined and improved our approach for future projects. Further, we have found that survivor-leaders, law enforcement, advocacy and social service have essential expertise and want to contribute to research that helps identify effective interdiction options in relation to human trafficking. In an end-of-grant survey, the survivor-centered advisory group reported feeling validated as knowledgeable leaders through our project and acknowledge that trust had been built among the members of the survivor-centered advisory group and the other research team members.

In short, this project built a strong team and a foundation for future work that has the potential to significantly improve research contributions to effective prevention, intervention and disruption of human trafficking by providing timely and accurate information to practitioners in the field. The diverse and complementary perspectives team members brought to the project were illuminating for all of us and fostered mutual respect. This project has convinced us that such transdisciplinary collaboration is necessary if we are to make meaningful progress against human trafficking and other complex social problems facing our nation.

 


Last Modified: 01/06/2021
Modified by: Lauren E Martin
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Human trafficking for sexual exploitation is a human rights violation with significant public health implications. It is hidden, illegal, and dangerous; therefore it is difficult to research and identify effective prevention, intervention and disruption strategies. Significant ethical challenges confront research on human trafficking, including risks of re-traumatization of victim/survivors. Modeling human trafficking operations and networks with mathematics offers the possibility of identifying effective actions to disrupt and prevent victimization while weighing the relative merits and costs/benefits of different strategies. This information is vital for stakeholders in the field to make informed decisions about disruption efforts. Models are only as good as the data used to build them. Useful models require accurate empirical data to inform assumptions and results. Yet, we lack a research-based understanding of the unique aspects of trafficking networks including their structure, function and processes. This project addresses this information gap. We formed a unique, transdisciplinary team to gather a wide-range of data from different sources and develop mathematical network models of trafficking operations. The project built a highly-functional team including qualitative researchers with expertise on trafficking, operations researchers, survivors of human trafficking, and law enforcement. We achieved the following high-level goals: (1) Identified operational structures of sex trafficking networks that make them unique among illicit supply networks. (2) Identified and translated qualitative data necessary to populate dynamic operations research models, such as interdiction models, that can disrupt such networks. (3) Built a highly functional cross-disciplinary and multi-sector team. (4) Worked together to verify that model assumptions are accurate by triangulating sources and exploring the project findings with a survivor-centered advisory group. (5) Identified ethical challenges and considerations in modeling, such as the need to acknowledge the complexity of human experiences and the inability of models to truly portray the violence and coercion embedded within human trafficking. The team completed all project objectives, including the following outcomes. We conducted 10 scoping interviews with stakeholders including police, service providers and survivors of trafficking to identify key elements of human trafficking operations and networks. We also conducted a thorough review of the literature and a secondary review of relevant interview data collected by past projects of PI Martin (N=246). A survivor-centered advisory group was convened to review all aspects of the project. This group met almost monthly for 18 months to highlight information missing from other sources and raise ethical and moral implications of the work. The University of Minnesota created a data-sharing agreement with the Minnesota Bureau of Criminal Apprehension (BCA) to conduct a pilot review of comprehensive investigative case files (N=2) to better understand the complexity of networks of human trafficking and the type of data contained in police case files. Each case was more than 1,000 pages long. The team created a data processing framework to transform key qualitative data into network data necessary for mathematical modeling. We also developed computational code to create node/arc visualizations of human trafficking operations. Network data was collected from publically available documents from 15 federally prosecuted trafficking cases and BCA cases using our processing framework. A new concept and initial computational code for a network generator was created. It will enable us to develop generic models of human trafficking networks based on empirical data and address ethical considerations with respect to confidentiality, privacy, and re-traumatization of victims. During the grant period, the team presented our findings to diverse audiences and drafted manuscripts for publication related to our modeling approach, computational code, qualitative understanding of operational networks and structure, and team science. Using a deliberate process of team-building in combination with a meta-study of ourselves, we cultivated shared language, better cross-disciplinary understanding, and deep working relationships among the transdisciplinary and cross-sector team. We documented our collaborative process using qualitative research. Based on this project we refined and improved our approach for future projects. Further, we have found that survivor-leaders, law enforcement, advocacy and social service have essential expertise and want to contribute to research that helps identify effective interdiction options in relation to human trafficking. In an end-of-grant survey, the survivor-centered advisory group reported feeling validated as knowledgeable leaders through our project and acknowledge that trust had been built among the members of the survivor-centered advisory group and the other research team members. In short, this project built a strong team and a foundation for future work that has the potential to significantly improve research contributions to effective prevention, intervention and disruption of human trafficking by providing timely and accurate information to practitioners in the field. The diverse and complementary perspectives team members brought to the project were illuminating for all of us and fostered mutual respect. This project has convinced us that such transdisciplinary collaboration is necessary if we are to make meaningful progress against human trafficking and other complex social problems facing our nation.
